The New York Attorney General announced a $75 million settlement -- $50 million in restitution and $25 million in fee reductions -- with Waddell & Reed to resolve allegations of unlawful trading of mutual funds through market timing. The $50 million portion of the settlement was negotiated together with the SEC, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-waddell-and-reed-inc

Company: Wheelabrator Saugus, Wheelabrator Andover and Wheelabrator Millbury
Description: The operator of Wheelabrator Saugus, Wheelabrator Andover and Wheelabrator Millbury agreed to pay $7.5 million in settlement of allegations the facilities committed multiple violations of the Hazardous Waste Management Act, the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act and the Wetlands Protection Act, by failing to properly treat and dispose of ash.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority censured and fined Macquarie Capital (USA) Inc. $2.95 million for failing to provide complete and accurate trade data in an automated format when requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD resolved its action against Waddell & Reed, Inc., of Overland Park, KS, arising from thousands of variable annuity exchanges made as part of the firm's national switching campaign. Under the terms of the settlement with NASD and a separate agreement with a coalition of state regulatory authorities, Waddell & Reed was to repay up to $11 million to more than 5,000 customers whose annuities were exchanged by the firm as well as a fine of $5 million to NASD. The resolution was also announced by a group of state regulators to which the firm paid an additional fine of $2 million: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-waddell-and-reed-inc-0
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Agency: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection

Description: The settlement involved a fuel audit of Cleco Power LLC and issues resulting from approximately $23 million in improper trading admitted by Cleco. The company first reported the illegal trading in November 2002.
